entry.title: Python contents
entry.content:
Forward

Welcome to my series of python articles for absolute beginers. The articles below are designed to help people with no experience (other than using a computer) to get started with programming, and particularly with python. They are written with the aim of helping people coming from a social science background to transition away from programs like SPSS and MS Excel and so a lot of the examples are childishly simple, especially in the earlier articles.

If you are new to python, I'm sure you will enjoy the journey. Just be patient and remember that its OK if you need a few tutorials, from a few different sources, before something clicks. Sometimes you have hear the same thing said multiple different ways before it perculates down into your head. If you find that my explanaitions don't work for you I can really hightly recomend these youtube tutorials and this book. They really helped me advance when I was just starting out.

If you're a seasoned python data scientist, then please look on this site with a kind eye, my aim has been to break everything down so that nothing is taken for granted or assumed because I found that people who are good at coding tend to take a lot for granted when teaching new people. This can be really disheartening and leave new folk feeling like they will never progress without a comp-sci degree and a background in building linux systems.

********* Content **********

  1. The Mindshift. This is a quick post about a mindset that might be useful to you as you begin to journey into working in code.

  2. Setting up a place to work. Get python installed and take a quick tour of Spyder, the main tool you'll be using as you follow these posts.

  3. Starting with strings. We begin working with actual information in python by looking at how python handles everyday English. This is where you are introduced to your first python data class, the string.

  4. Numbers in python. From normal everyday English language, we move onto normal everyday numbers and you are introduced to two new python data classes; ints and floats.

  5. Python Variables. Now that we have a few data classes under our belt, we can start to think about assigning information, like strings or numbers, to python variables.

Check back soon for more beginers python posts.

Hold on tight, you got this!

Kev

entry.title: Variables.
entry.content:
Disclaimer

What follows is not written to be 100% accurate in all the technical detail. It is written to help people with limited knowledge of computers to get started with using python. As such, I have tried to limit jargon so if you already know terms like "object" and "class", or what a command line is, then this page ain't for you. Feel free to stick around though.

Variables

You now know that python handles everyday language as strings and that numbers can be treated as either ints or floats, noice! What you've actually done is played with data objects in python for the first time, and you've already done so with 3 different classes of data.

Data is just information, and, in very simplistic terms, coding languages like python are really good at doing stuff with information. Strings, ints, and floats are just different types (or classes) of data. There are lots of other data classes but for now we're just going to stick with these basic one.

The first thing we're going to cover is called assigning variables. This just refers to the process of taking a piece of data (information) and giving it a name that python can use to quickly find and work with that data. This is really easy to do with python.

Lets take a piece of text that we want to work with.

"When a thought of war comes, oppose it by a stronger thought of peace."

You can also think of that sentence as a pice of information/data, or as an object within python. This object happens to be of the string class but that doesn't matter for right now. What matters is that you can take that whole object (everything between the quotation marks) and give it short name that you can use to refer to the entire object without having to type it all out everytime you want to do something with it. This process is called assigning to a variable and it's really really easy.

s = "When a thought of war comes, oppose it by a stronger thought of peace."

The chunk of code above is simple but it packs a punch, lets walk through it.

The lower case s at the begining is the short name (or variable) that we are giving to the string, the = sign is the symbol that we use to do the assignment, and the string is object that we are assigning. To translate this into everyday speech it would read as:

This string is now called s.

One of the things that trips people up is the grammer of the code chunk is acctually the other way around:

s is the name of that string.

The second version is more accurate and I've found it useful to just settle that structure in my mind:

  1. variable name
  2. =
  3. the piece of data

Lets look at another example.

m = 12 
a = 40 
f = m*a

print(f)

In the first line, we assign m the value of 12. In the second line we give a the value of 40 and in the last line we give f the value of m multiplied by a. So in this example we have assigned three objects to three variables:

Object 1. the int 12
Object 2. the int 40
Object 3. the product of 12 multiplied by 40

Now, they are called variables because they can change, or to put it another way, the object assigned to that variable can be updated. Lets imagine that m is the mass of a car and a is its acceleration. Lets say we are getting m and a from some measurement devices that are connected to our computer, like a weighing scales for m and speedometer for a. By multiplying m and a together we get the Force the car is exherting as it travels (f). If the car speeds up or slows down a also changes, likewise if someone exits or enters the car m will change. In both cases the object is changing, or varying, which means that f is also changing, or varying.... get it? They're variables... Sorry.

Naming variables

You could have used pretty much any word or letter as the variable names, excluding spaces and punctuation. This means that 

m = 12 
a = 40 
f = m*a

print(f)

is the same as 

banana = 12 
apple = 40 
fruit = m*a

print(fruit)

However you can use _ (underscores) and you're encouraged to do so.

car_mass = 12 
car_acceleration = 40 
car_force = m*a

print(car_force)

It's best to use simple and informative names and to be consistent in your naming convention. Without going into why, python users tend to prefer using underscores when linking words together and to balance brevity with clarity so that 'car_accel' might be better than 'car_acceleration' because the later is cumbersome to type, although personally, I think both options need work. As you get more practice in you will develop a taste for how you like to name variables.

So now you know how to assign a variable, and you know that strings, ints, and floats are data types that can be assigned. Next time we'll go over more complex types of data objects, and from there we'll get to doing actually work with objects. If you want to read into this more then this page on the real python website will give you more detail on what was covered in this post.

If you want to, you could practice assigning some variables and printing them in Spyder. Assign a variable, press enter the type 'print(your variable)' and press enter again. Do this to your heart's content, try reusing the same name a few times and seen what happens when you print the variable after change it.

Well done! Thats another basic concept covered, give yourself a pat on the back.

Next time we are going to cover what that 'print()' thing is and how you can use things like it in your own code. I think you'll really like it.

See you then,

Kev

entry.title: Numbers in python
entry.content:
Disclaimer

What follows is not written to be 100% accurate in all the technical detail. It is written to help people with limited knowledge of computers to get started with using python. As such, I have tried to limit jargon so if you already know terms like "object" and "class", or what a command line is, then this page ain't for you. Feel free to stick around though.

You now know how to make strings like a boss, meaning that when it comes to typing the language you use in everyday life you have the basics under your belt. What we're moving onto now is something that comes to mind more often when people think of computers:

Numbers

Don't worry, we're not getting into complex maths, we're just going get used to playing with simple numbers in python.

Ints

The first way that python handles numbers is as the "int" type. This is basically just a whole number like 9 or 42(hehe) or 7000000000, the way you use numbers every day as you go through your life, doing numbery things... like counting "likes"... or what ever it is you people do.

Floats

The other way that python works with numbers is as floating-point numbers, of the "float" type. Just like ints, floats are pretty simple, they're just numbers followed by a decimal point. So 13.333333 is a float, and so is 0.2 etc. You know the deal.

Strings

Hopefully, you remember that when using normal langauge in python you use quotation marks to tell python what it is.

"Like this. Python knows that this is a string."

You can also, and hopefully this occured to you already, use numbers in your strings if you want to.

"Python also knows that this 2nd sentence is a string. I could put 3 numbers in this string if I wanted!"

This means you can write numbers into your sentences if you want to, but doing so this was means you can't do anything with those numbers. Yet! There is loads of ways you interact with strings and numbers that allow you to automate or update the numbers in a sentence, like when you need to update a report for example, and we'll get there. In the meantime just remember that there are ints, which are whole numbers, floats, numbers with decimal points, and strings, which is just using numberic symbols in normal language.

(Really) Simple math

So, when it comes to numbers, python will recognise a number, that isn't wrapped in quotes, as a number. This means you can just give python a number and every math instructions and python will give you back the result (again, we're taking it really slowly, you can do more than that). The usual math symbols, like + and - work just fine so lets just start there.

If you're still working in Spyder then you can pop into the terminal and type in a simple math problem like I've shown below. Once you press enter you'll get the answer to your math problem.

Note You might need to press enter twice to get python to run the math.

Et Voila! You've just done your first mathematical operation in python! Was it a small operation? Maybe, but you should be proud of yourself, it was the first of many. In the next post, we're going to cover more complex operations with numbers and strings by looking at the various 'operators', or symbols, you can use as instructions to tell python what to do.

Well done so far, keep up the good work!

Kev

entry.title: Setting up a place to work
entry.content:
Disclaimer

What follows is not written to be 100% accurate in all the technical detail. It is written to help people with limited knowledge of computers to get started with using python. As such, I have tried to limit jargon so if you already know terms like "object" and "class", or what a command line is, then this page ain't for you. Feel free to stick around though.

I'm assuming you've read my first post on this topic, it's about a mindset that might be useful to you if you're new here. If you have, or you just want to get started, read on.

Getting started in python and spyder

The first thing you need to do is make sure that python is installed on your computer and up to date. There's a few ways to do this, and if you have a Mac it's already there, but your fastest bet is to install anaconda, which installs python and a few good programs that let you write and run code.

These programs are called Integrated Development Environments, but don't worry about that right now. The short version is they let you work on projects without needing to have loads of windows open on your computer.

Once you have installed anaconda, open it up and you'll be presented with a grid of different "apps" (that's not the right term but we're gonna use it here) laid out in a grid. Now, you're free to use any of these apps and there's loads of reason to use each one, but I'm going to work in spyder because... well just because. I was advised to use spyder when I started out, and although I've moved on since, I'm advising you to do the same.

So click "launch" on the spyder app and away we go...

Spyder consists of 3 seperate panes:

  1. The text editor, this is where you can write and edit code.
  2. The console, where your code runs (hopefully).
  3. The 3rd pane, which does multiple things, like let you view your variables and plots, find files etc. It's a good pane, I like it. It's kinda why we're using spyder.

The text editor.

So, I'm going to assume that you have edited text before, you've used Word, or written a facebook post/tweet? Well, in the simplest terms, the text editor is like a word page or a status box. You write in it, you can delete, jump around, copy and paste... do texty-things. In general you want to write code in here but you can include everyday language as well when you want to explain something, but we'll get to that later. What you need to take away from this is the text editor is like Word or Pages, you write your "document" (in this case some code) and can freely edit it from there. The cool thing is that you can tell the computer to read what you have written in the text editor, as a set of instructions, in the order you've written it, and the computer will do it.

You can get the computer to read the whole document from top to bottom, or start in the middle, or just run the last bit, but really, you want to think of your code here like a story; it has a begining, a middle, and an end. You should be aiming to have it read like that with no jumping around.At least, once you've finished editing.

One of the first things you'll do is make things show up in the console.

The Console.

The console is where the magic happens. When you tell your computer to do something, the console is where your computer will tell you what's happening. So if you tell your computer to say "Hello World!", unless otherwise stated you'll see:

"Hello World!"

in the console.

You can also write code dierctly into the console and when you press enter the code will run, with the output appearing directly below the code you wrote. Honestly, I don't do that often because it looks messy. However, if I want to do something just once I will jump into the console. 

print("Hello World!")

>>>Hello World!

Also, if your code doesn't work for some reason the console is where you find out what went wrong by showing you an error report. In essence, this is a just a guide that tell's you what went wrong and where in your code the problem is. I'm about to show you a chunk of code that you won't understand. Don't panic.

print(hello world)#this is a bit of python code that doesn't work. 


  File "/Users/kevinomalley/Desktop/traceback_test.py", line 1
    print(hello world)
                    ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax

Again, don't panic. At first, things like this look scary, but really all it means is there is a typo in my code (compare the two black boxes to see if you can spot the difference), and where to find it. We'll cover this more fully later on, but what I want you to take away from this is that the console is your friend:

  1. It is where the result of your code shows up.
  2. It can let you run a little bit of code just to check and see if it's what you want
  3. It tells you if somethings gone wrong and where to find the problem.

Good console. Lovely console.

The 3rd pane.

The 3rd pane in spyder is basically kind of a catch all. If you need to find output the console can't handle, like a graph, it'll be in there. If you want to open a file without leaving spyder, you can use that pane. If you've saved something as a variable (we'll cover what that means later), go to the 3rd pane to check it out.

The most useful bit, that is really often overlooked is the "Help" tab. Now, I'm gonna be honest with you here, at the very begining the help you get there is... not... amazing. You have to know a a fair amount of what's going on for it to be useful. That said it's worth using often, mainly because it'll get you comfortable with the jargon as you pick through what it means. To use it just highlight some text in the editor window and press control and i at the same time (command and i on a Mac) and an explanaition of the code will pop up in that box. It's something we'll touch off again a few times when we have our feet under the table a little more.

OK, now what?

What I've tried to do here is introduce you to one of the options you have for working with python, and give you a tour of what you're looking at so that it is no longer some dark world. There's a lot more going on and we'll get there, but as I've said from the outset, the point of this whole site is to take really really small steps to make you feel comfortable.

What should you take away with you?

  1. You can write code in either the text editor or the console. For quick, small chunks the console is fine, but when it comes to writing your coding opus, or code you acctually want other people to read, that should be in the text editor.
  2. When you run code, whatever that code produces will show up in the console (for the most part). If it's an error, thats ok, they may look scary but they're actually really useful. That doesn't mean you want to see them too often, but when they show up, try not to feel bad.
  3. The 3rd pane is like a catch-all for the other stuff, either files you want to open that are somewhere else on your computer, or for the results of some code that can't go to the console (like a fancy pants scatter plot).

With that in place you should be good and ready to start playing around in python using spyder as your playground. In the next post we'll cover the smallest bits of python that you'll come across often, integers, floats and strings. once you get used to playing with them you'll start to see the power of what you can do with code.

Kev.

Post Script I don't really use spyder that much anymore, not because it's not cool, but because I've started using Sublime Text 3. There are literally loads of programs you can use, and at least twice as many opinions on which is best. When you get comfortable with what's going on in spyder maybe start playing around with other IDE's. You'll find something that suits you, and then you may find that what suits you changes. It's all good.

entry.title: Starting with strings
entry.content:
Disclaimer

What follows is not written to be 100% accurate in all the technical detail. It is written to help people with limited knowledge of computers to get started with using python. As such, I have tried to limit jargon so if you already know terms like "object" and "class", or what a command line is, then this page ain't for you. Feel free to stick around though.

OK, now that you have installed python and a program that lets you do python-y things its time to acutally....start doing python-y things.

So, we're going to start with the way that you can type normal, everyday, English into python and have it recognised as such:

Strings!

A string is just a collection of alphanumeric text (letters and numbers and punctuation), and it's the first example of a python class we're meeting. Now we're not going to cover classes here, it'll become clear over time, but what you need to know right now is that a class is the general name for something that python can work with. Strings are one type of class, there are many others, and eventually you'll even be able to make your own!

Fine Kev, get on with it!

OK, sorry! Sorry!

I've just told you that python has a a way dealing with normal langauge, the trick is that you have wrap that text in quotes, otherwise python doesn't know what to do with it. 

'Check out the apostrophies at the begining and the end of this sentence!'

Boom. we have our first string! Python can read that sentence and can do stuff with it, awesome. However, let's take a look at another sentence and see if we can make a string out of it. 

'Making strings is awesome, let's do some more!'

See the problem? Python treats the first apostrophe as the start of the string and the second apostrophe as the end of the string, even though it's not actually the end of the sentence. Now, we could just avoid every typing a contraction like "can't" or "didn't", and avoid Irish or Scottish surnames begining with O, but that seems like a special hell, does it not?

Fortunately there's a simple fix; when we want to enter a string that includes an apostrophe in the text we use double quotes " ", standard quotation marks.

"Now ain't this a pretty string?"

Now, you may ask yourself

Why not just use " " every time?

The truth is I don't know why python gives you two options for designating a line of text as a string, but one thought I had is that it's faster to type 'hi' than it is to type "hi" because the second one requires that you hold down the shift key.

There's some pretty cool things we can do with strings, but I'm gonna hold off on that for a little while. Before, we finish talking about strings though there's one last thing you should know, even though it won't come up a lot. That's how to handle strings that are more than one line long. 

'''This is a multi line string, it allows me to write
sentences that go on more than one line.'''

To make a string that goes on more than one line you can use three apostrophies at the begining and the end ''' '''. This would allow you to type your magnum opus, or a delightful poem. But most frequently the strings you write are going to be pretty short so you just need apostrophies or quotation marks. There is a use for the tripple apostroie format called "docstrings" but we're a ways away from needing them, just remember that you can use them if you need to write a long string.

OK, so now that you have seen how to make strings lets do your first bit of code. Go into the console in spyder and type 'Hello World!' and then press enter. You'll see something similar to the image below.

You just did your first thing in python!! Now granted, it wasn't very impressive... but hey, you still did it! Now to make your first error (trust me it'll be fine). Go back to the console and type Hello World, but leave out the apostrophies this time.

And there it is! This is the first of many such errors. You'll see them often, especially when you start out, but as you progress you'll understand that they are really just a tool to make sure you get better and better.

OK so now you know what strings are, and how to make them. Soon you'll doing awesome stuff with them. For right now though we're going to put strings aside, just for a minute and next we'll move onto using numbers in python. Not like crazy complicate number, just normal, everyday numbers. I promise it's easy.

Kev

entry.title: The Mindshift.
entry.content:
So, for some reason, you've decide decided that learning python would be a good thing to do. Great! I agree with you completely.

Well... of course I do or this site would be pointless...

We're going to get to the cool stuff in a minute but before we crack on I want to try to get an idea into your head that will be useful. For a lot of people nowadays, the process of using a computer, or phone, is the process of finding the right button and asking Friend Computer to do something for you, and quite often, that's ok.

However, for people who actually work on computers learning to code allows you to take on a slightly different mindset:

You're not asking the computer to do something, you're telling the computer what to do.

From my experience teaching people data analysis with SPSS, I often see students "beseaching" the software to work, fearfully proffering thier data, seeking out the right buttons and then struggling to parse the output into an assignment or a paper, while not having a conceptual grasp of whats happening in the background. When using something like python, however, you are literally giving the computer instructions, you're the boss. The computer is working for you, doing your bidding.

Is that a subtle difference? Sure, but it's a meaningful one. Instead of being stuck with what the computer gives you, you tell it what you want, and (eventually) where you want it, and in what format.

So while I understand that people find learning to code to be intimidating, I want to ask you to see yourself as the hero of this journey. Not like the barbarian, more like the wizard. You will learn what you, get better and better, and slay all kinds of Dragons.

I dunno about you, but I'd rather be using tools and bending things to my will... I mean... being proactive.

So buckle up traveler and lets get to gettin'.
